People's Republic}} (since 2014) *{{flagicon|Catalonia}} [[Catalan declaration of independence|Catalan Republic]] (2017) ==List by type== In modern usage, a republican system of government is loosely applied to any state which claims this designation.[http://dictionary.oed.com/cgi/entry/50203498?single=1&query_type=word&queryword=republic&first=1&max_to_show=10 Republic], ''Oxford English Dictionary'', SECOND EDITION 1989 For example, the [[Dominican Republic]] under [[Rafael Trujillo]] is considered a republic, as is the [[Republic of Iraq]] under [[Saddam Hussein]] and [[The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics]] under [[Joseph Stalin]]. The [[Kingdom of Sweden]] (which in 2006 ranked highest in the Economist's index of democracy) Laza Kekic, [http://www.economist.com/media/pdf/DEMOCRACY_INDEX_2007_v3.pdf The Economist Intelligence Units Index of democracy], ''The Economist: The World in 2007'' is not a republic, but the [[Democratic People's Republic of Korea]] (i.e. North Korea, which ranks lowest in the same survey) is. ===Arab Republics=== *{{flagicon|Egypt}} [[Arab Republic of Egypt]] *{{flagicon|Syria}} [[Syrian Arab Republic]] *{{flagicon|United Arab Republic}} [[United Arab Republic]] (1958–1971) *{{flagicon|North Yemen}} [[Yemen Arab Republic]] (1962–1990) *{{Flagicon|Libya|variant = 1977}} [[History of Libya under Muammar Gaddafi#Libyan Arab Republic .281969.E2.80.931977.29|Libyan Arab Republic]] (1969–1977) ===Confederal Republics=== [[confederation|Confederal republics]] are associations of sovereign states, usually having power over critical common issues such as [[National security|defense]] and [[foreign policy]]: *{{flagicon|Confederate States of America}} [[Confederate States of America]] (1861–1865) *{{flagicon|Senegal}} {{flagicon|Gambia}} [[Senegambia Confederation]] (1982–1989) *{{flagicon|USA|1777}} [[United States of America]] (under the [[Articles of Confederation]], 1776–1789) ===Crowned Republics=== A [[crowned republic]], is a form of [[constitutional monarchy]] where the monarch's role is commonly seen as largely ceremonial and where all the royal prerogatives are prescribed by custom and law in such a way that the monarch has limited discretion over governmental and constitutional issues. {{Div col}} *{{flagicon|United Kingdom}} [[United Kingdom]] (1707-present){{Cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=DKA2ZIkJaM0C&pg=PA405&dq=crowned+republic+united+kingdom&hl=el&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwix0p6QxfjeAhVDglwKHRefAugQ6AEINzAC#v=onepage&q=crowned%2520republic%2520united%2520kingdom&f=false |title=A Short History of the World |last=Wells |first=H. G. |date=2005-12-01 |publisher=Cosimo, Inc. |isbn=9781596055858 |language=en}} *{{flagicon|Norway}} [[Kingdom of Norway]] (1905-present){{Cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=BKNWAAAAYAAJ&q=crowned+republic+norway&dq=crowned+republic+norway&hl=el&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjPxdXWxfjeAhVCQMAKHXBgCEUQ6AEISjAE |title=The American Political Science Review |last=Willoughby |first=Westel Woodbury |last2=Fairlie |first2=John Archibald |last3=Ogg |first3=Frederic Austin |date=1918 |publisher=American Political Science Association. |language=en}}{{additional citation needed|date=November 2018}} *{{flagicon|Australia}} [[Commonwealth of Australia]] (1986-present){{Cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=hc4p65yM_hYC&pg=PA105&dq=%2522Crowned+republic%2522&ei=iespTKzWFJTelQSwn7WPDg&cd=3&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%2522Crowned%2520republic%2522&f=false |title=Choosing the Republic |last=Patmore |first=Glenn |date=2009 |publisher=University of New South Wales Press |isbn=9781742230153 |language=en}} *{{flagicon|New Zealand}} [[Realm of New Zealand]] (1947-present) *{{flagicon|Canada}} [[Canada]] (1982-present) *{{flagicon|Papua New Guinea}} [[Independent State of Papua New Guinea]] (1975-present) *{{flagicon|Jamaica}} [[Jamaica]] (1962-present) *{{flagicon|Solomon Islands}} [[Solomon Islands]] (1978-present) *{{flagicon|The Bahamas}} [[Commonwealth of The Bahamas]] (1973-present) *{{flagicon|Belize}} [[Belize]] (1981-present) *{{flagicon|Barbados}} [[Barbados]] (1966-present) *{{flagicon|Saint Lucia}} [[Saint Lucia]] (1979-present) *{{flagicon|Saint Vincent and the Grenadines}} [[Saint Vincent and the Grenadines]] (1979-present) *{{flagicon|Grenada}} [[Grenada]] (1984-present) *{{flagicon|Antigua and Barbuda}} [[Antigua and Barbuda]] (1981-present) *{{flagicon|Saint Kitts and Nevis}} [[Federation of Saint Christopher and Nevis]] (1983-present) *{{flagicon|Tuvalu}} [[Tuvalu]] (1978-present) *{{flagicon|Japan}} [[State of Japan]] (1952-present) *{{flagicon|Sweden}} [[Kingdom of Sweden]] (1905-present) *{{flagicon|Denmark}} [[Kingdom of Denmark]] (1948-present) *{{flagicon|Netherlands}} [[Kingdom of the Netherlands]] (1954-present) *{{flagicon|Liechtenstein}} [[Principality of Liechtenstein]] (1866-present) *{{flagicon|Luxembourg}} [[Grand Duchy of Luxembourg]] (1958-present) *{{flagicon|Belgium}} [[Kingdom of Belgium]] (1839-present) *{{flagicon|Kingdom of Greece}} [[Kingdom of Greece]] (1864-1967){{Cite web |url=http://anemi.lib.uoc.gr/php/pdf_pager.php?rec=/metadata/a/f/b/metadata-01-0002588.tkl&do=279838_10.pdf&pageno=264&pagestart=1&width=662&height=963&maxpage=1104&lang=en |title=Ελλάς (Πολίτευμα) |year=1934 |website=www.anemi.lib.uoc.gr |publisher=Pyrsos Publishing |location=Athens |page=239 |language=Greek |trans-title=Greece (Form of Government) |access-date=2018-08-31 |quote=Through the Constitution of 1864, constitutional monarchy, or, as it had been described, "crowned democracy", or "democratic monarchy", was consolidated as the form of government in Greece.}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.hellenicparliament.gr/UserFiles/f3c70a23-7696-49db-9148-f24dce6a27c8/syn16.pdf |title=Σύνταγμα της Ελλάδος |year=1952 |website=www.hellenicparliament.gr |publisher=[[Hellenic Parliament]] |location=Athens |page=6 |language=Greek |trans-title=Constitution of Greece |access-date=2018-08-31 |quote=Article 21: The Form of Government of Greece is that of a Crowned Republic. All powers stem from the Nation and are excercised in accordance with the Constitution.}} *{{flagicon|Union of South Africa}} [[Union of South Africa]] (1910-1961) *{{flagicon|Ceylon}} [[Dominion of Ceylon]] (1948-1972) *{{flagicon|Fiji}} [[Dominion of Fiji]] (1970-1987) *{{flagicon|Gambia}} [[The Gambia (1965–1970)|The Gambia]] (1965-1970) *{{flagicon|Ghana}} [[Dominion of Ghana]] (1957-1960) *{{flagicon|Guyana}} [[Guyana (1966–1970)|Guyana]] (1966–1970) *{{flagicon|Trinidad and Tobago}} [[Dominion of Trinidad and Tobago]] (1962-1976) {{Div col end}} ===Democratic Republics=== These are republics that use the word "democratic" in their official name. Their actual political systems can vary considerably but are usually un-democratic communist states. {{Div col}} *{{flagicon|North Korea}} [[Democratic People's Republic of Korea]] (1948–present) *{{flagicon|DR Congo}} [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] (1966–1971, 1997–present) *{{flagicon|Sao Tome and Principe}} [[Democratic Republic of São Tomé and Príncipe]] (1975–present) *{{flagicon|East Timor}} [[Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste]] (1975–present) *{{flagicon|North Vietnam}} [[Democratic Republic of Vietnam]] (1945–1975) *{{flagicon|Sri Lanka}} [[Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka]] (1978–present) *{{flagicon|Ethiopia}} [[Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia]] (1991–present) *{{flagicon|Nepal}} [[Federal Democratic Republic of Nepal]] (2008–present) *{{flagicon|East Germany}} [[German Democratic Republic]] (1949–1990) *{{flagicon|Laos}} [[Lao People's Democratic Republic]] (1975–present) *{{flagicon|Algeria}} [[People's Democratic Republic of Algeria]] (1962–present) *{{flagicon|South Yemen}} [[People's Democratic Republic of Yemen]] (1967–1990) {{Div col end}} ===Federal Republics=== [[Federal republic]]s are [[federal state]]s in which the [[administrative division]]s (states or provinces) theoretically retain a degree of autonomy which is constitutionally protected, and cannot be revoked unilaterally by the national government. Federal republics are not unitary states. {{Div col}} *{{flagicon|Venezuela}} [[Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela]] *{{flagicon|Bosnia and Herzegovina}} [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] (since 1995) *{{flagicon|England}} [[Commonwealth of England]] (1649–1653) *{{flagicon|Czechoslovakia}} [[Czechoslovakia]]: [[Czechoslovak Socialist Republic]] (1969–1990), [[Czech and Slovak Federative Republic]] (1990–1992) *{{flagicon|Ethiopia|1974}} [[Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia]] (unitary republic 1974–1994; federal republic since 1994) *{{flagicon|Cameroon|1961}} [[Federal Republic of Cameroon]] (1961–1972) *{{flagicon|Somalia}} [[Federal Republic of Somalia]] (since August 2012) *{{flagicon|Brazil}} [[Federative Republic of Brazil]] (since November 15, 1889)___."The Formation of the Brazilian Republic in 1889." (accessed May 19, 2008). *{{flagicon|Germany}} [[Germany|Federal Republic of Germany]] (since 1918) *{{flagicon|Gran Colombia}} [[Gran Colombia]] (Republic of Colombia) (1819–1886), known as [[Great Colombia]] from 1819 to 1831, when it included present-day [[Ecuador]], [[Venezuela]] and [[Panama]]. *{{flagicon|Mexico|1823}} [[Second Federal Republic of Mexico]] (1846–1864) *{{flagicon|Mexico}} [[United Mexican States]]{{cite web |url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/mx.html |title=Mexico |accessdate=2007-12-21 |year=2007 |work=[[The World Factbook]] |publisher=[[CIA]]}} (since 1917) *{{flagicon|Nepal}} [[Federal Democratic Republic of Nepal]] (since 2007){{cite web |url=http://www.gorkhapatra.org.np/content.php?nid=33139 |title=Nepal declared republican state – Gorkhapatra Sansthan - State Owned Newspaper |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20070726190528/http://www.gorkhapatra.org.np/content.php?nid=33139 |archivedate=2007-07-26 |df= }} *{{flagicon|Nigeria}} [[Federal Republic of Nigeria]] (1963–66:[[Nigerian First Republic|1st Republic]], 1979–83: [[Nigerian Second Republic|2nd Republic]], 1993: [[Nigerian Third Republic|3rd Republic]], 1999–present: [[Nigerian Fourth Republic|4th Republic]]) *{{flagicon|Argentina}} [[Argentine Republic]] (since 1852) *{{flagicon|India}} [[Republic of India]] (since January 26, 1950) *{{flagicon|South Sudan}} [[Republic of South Sudan]] (since 9 July 2011) *{{flagicon|Sudan}} [[Republic of Sudan]] (since 1 January 1956) *{{flagicon|Austria}} [[Republic of Austria]] *{{flagicon|Russia}} [[Russian Federation]] (since [[October Revolution|November 7, 1917]]; up to 1991 it was named ''[[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic]]''[[Supreme Soviet of Russia|Supreme Soviet of the Russian SFSR]] approved the Law of the RSFSR #2094-I of December 25, 1991 [https://web.archive.org/web/20060529112856/http://humanities.edu.ru/db/msg/12047 "Name Change for the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic"] // News of the Congress of People's Deputies of the Russian SFSR and Supreme Soviet of the Russian SFSR. – 1992. – № 2. – Art. 62)[http://www.constitution.ru/en/10003000-02.htm Article 1 of the Russian Constitution] *{{flagicon|Serbia and Montenegro}} [[State Union of Serbia and Montenegro]] (2003–2006) *{{flag|Switzerland}} (1848-present), a federal republic but called the Swiss Confederation *{{flagicon|Soviet Union}} [[Union of Soviet Socialist Republics]] (1922–1991) *{{flagicon|United Provinces of Central America}} [[United Provinces of Central America]] (1823–1840) *{{flagicon|USA}} [[United States of America]]{{cite web |url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/us.html |title=United States |accessdate=2007-12-21 |year=2007 |work=[[The World Factbook]] |publisher=[[CIA]]}} (since 1789) *{{flagicon|Indonesia}} [[United States of Indonesia]] (1949–1950) *{{flagicon|Yugoslavia}} [[Yugoslavia]]: [[Federal People's Republic of Yugoslavia]] (1946–1963), [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia]] (1963–1992), [[Federal Republic of Yugoslavia]] (1992–2003) {{Div col end}} ===Islamic Republics=== Republics governed in accordance with Islamic law: *{{flagicon|Afghanistan}} [[Islamic Republic of Afghanistan]] (since 2004) *{{flagicon|Iran}} [[Islamic Republic of Iran]] (since 1979) *{{flagicon|Mauritania}} [[Islamic Republic of Mauritania]] (since 1960) *{{flagicon|Pakistan}} [[Islamic Republic of Pakistan]] (since 1956) ===People's Republics=== People's republics are said to be governed by the people. The name is most often (but not always) used by [[communist state]]s. {{Div col}} *{{flagicon|North Korea}} [[Democratic People's Republic of Korea]] *{{flagicon|Algeria}} [[People's Democratic revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox mountain | name = Maglić | photo = Maglic.jpg | photo_caption = Maglić's peak covered with clouds. | photo_size = 250 | elevation_m = 2388 | elevation_ref = | prominence_m = | prominence_ref = | map = Bosnia and Herzegovina | map_caption = Location of Maglić in Bosnia and Herzegovina (on Montenegro border) | map_size = 250 | label_position = left | listing = [[List of countries by highest point|Country high point]] | location = {{flagicon|BIH}} [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] {{flagicon|MNE}} [[Montenegro]] | range = [[Dinaric Alps]]<ref>[http://www.peakbagger.com/peak.aspx?pid=10327 "Maglic" on Peakbagger] 27 September 2011</ref> | coordinates = {{coord|43|16|52|N|18|44|13|E|type:mountain_scale:100000|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | coordinates_ref = | topo = | type = [[Karst]] [[limestone]] | age = | first_ascent = | easiest_route = }} '''Maglić''' ({{lang-sr-cyrl|Маглић}}; {{IPA-sh|mǎɡliːtɕ|pron}}<ref>{{cite encyclopedia | editor = Pravopisna komisija | encyclopedia = Pravopis srpskohrvatskoga književnog jezika | title = Maglić | edition = Fototipsko izdanje 1988. | year = 1960 | publisher=Matica srpska, Matica hrvatska | location = Novi Sad, Zagreb | pages = 412}}</ref>) is the highest peak at an elevation of {{Convert|2386|m}} in the hill ranges of [[Plješevica]], [[Grmeč]], [[Cincar]] and [[Raduša (mountain)|Raduša]] in the country of [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]]. Maglić borders [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] and [[Montenegro]]. It is oriented in a northwest-southeast direction.<ref name=Maglic>{{Cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/356798/Maglic|title = Maglic|accessdate=10 July 2011|publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica}}</ref><ref name=Mountain>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mountainsmounts.com/mountain/17514/maglic/|title=Maglić Mountain|accessdate=10 July 2011|publisher=mountainsmounts.com}}</ref><ref name=Parks>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cgbhchicago.com/en/welcome-to-bosnia-and-herzegovina/tourism/national-park.html|title=National Parks|work=The Sutjeska National Park|accessdate=7 July 2011|publisher=Consul General of BiH in Chicago|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613115642/http://www.cgbhchicago.com/en/welcome-to-bosnia-and-herzegovina/tourism/national-park.html|archivedate=13 June 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Maglić is the highest mountain in Bosnia and Herzegovina. It lies within the [[Sutjeska National Park]], which was established in 1962. The park is drained by the [[Sutjeska (river)|Sutjeska River]], the watershed of the river is partly formed by the canyon parts of Maglić mountain; with [[Vučevo]] ({{Convert|1862|m}}) and [[Zelengora]] ({{Convert|2014|m}}) also forming part of the watershed boundary.<ref name=Parks/><ref name=National>{{Cite web|url=http://www.highlandertim.com/english/primeval_forest.html|title=National Park Sutjeska|accessdate=7 July 2011|publisher=Highlander|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711165403/http://www.highlandertim.com/english/primeval_forest.html|archivedate=11 July 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Geography== [[File:Trnovačko jezero, Maglić.jpg|thumb|left|250px|[[Trnovačko Lake]] bounded by Maglić]]
[[Foča]] city near the border with Montenegro is {{Convert|20|km}} away from the Maglić massif and the nearest town is Mratinje.<ref name=Summit/>[[Karst]] [[lime stone]] formations in the region of [[limestone|limestone plateau]] are the general geological setting in the south and southwest region.<ref name=Maglic/>
Maglić massif consists of two peaks namely, the Veliki Maglić ({{Convert|2386|m}}) on the Bosnia and Herzegovina side and the Crnogorski Maglić ({{Convert|2388|m}}) on the Montenegrin side, which is {{Convert|2|m}} higher. The Montenegrin part of Maglić massif has formed the Trnovačko Jezero ([[Trnovačko Lake]]), said to be "one of the most beautiful of Montenegro."<ref name=Mountain/><ref name=Summit>{{Cite web|url=http://www.summitpost.org/magli-263-bio-269-volujak-trnova-269-ki-durmitor-vlasulja/152180|title= Maglić / Bioč / Volujak / Trnovački Durmitor / Vlasulja|accessdate=11 July 2011|publisher=summitpost.org}}</ref> This lake is a glacier lake at an elevation of {{Convert|1517|m}}, is {{Convert|700|m}} long and {{Convert|400|m}} wide set amidst a "huge amphitheater of rocky peaks".{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} The lake is drained from the Maglić, the [[Volujak (mountain)|Volujak]] and the [[Bioč]] hill ranges. The north side of the lake which is open has the wooded [[Vratnice]]. The lake water has green-blue colour.<ref name=Summit/><ref>{{ cite web|url=http://folders.bosnie-herzegovina.net/greenvisions_brochure_2008.pdf|format=pdf|title=Green Visions and Outdoor Adventure and Culture Guide 2008 |work=Sutjeska National Park Hike|accessdate=11 July 2011|publisher=Green Visions}}</ref> The headwaters of Sutjeska River are in the canyon parts of Maglić Mountain. The mountain is bounded by the [[Sutjeska (river)|Sutjeska]] river on the north and west, by the Volujak mountain on the southwest, by the [[Drina River]] and [[Piva River]] on the east and by the [[Mratinjska Uvala]] valley on the south. It presents a challenging climb.<ref name=Mountain/><ref name=Summit/>
The rich forests on the mountainside consist of the [[Perućica]] forest, a protected reserve within the Sutjeska National Park, which is the oldest and one of the two last remaining primeval forests in Europe. The northwestern slope has thick coniferous and beech trees up to elevation {{Convert|1600|m}}, while in the other directions the hill slopes are very steep, barren and rocky. Pastures are found at elevations above {{Convert|1600|m}} in the plateaus.<ref name=National/><ref name=Sutje>{{cite web|url=http://www.visitsarajevo.ba/maps-guides/around-sarajevo/national-treasures/sutjeska|title=Sutjeska National Park|accessdate=11 July 2011|publisher=Visitsrajevo.ba}}</ref> The mountain peak is accessible through the park and is visited by mountaineers and nature lovers. Most of the routes to the peak require two days of hiking. Mountaineering access to the summit of the Maglić massif is only from the southern side, which has rich vegetation of grass and mountain pine. From the top of the peak, are scenic vistas of [[Volujak (mountain)|Volujak]], [[Bioč]], [[Trnovačko Lake]], [[Durmitor]] (in Montenegro), apart from the Bosnian mountains in the north and northwestern direction which can be seen.<ref name=Summit/>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Maglić|position=right}} * [http://www.zelengora.net/mape/maglic_karta.html Maglic hiking map]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Maglic (mountain)}} [[Category:Mountains of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] [[Category:Mountains of Montenegro]] [[Category:Bosnia and Herzegovina–Montenegro border]] [[Category:International mountains of Europe]] [[Category:Two-thousanders of Bosnia and Herzegovina]] [[Category:Two-thousanders of Montenegro]] [[Category:Highest points of countries]]

[[File:Devil's Marbles.jpg|200px|thumb|Nubbins of [[Karlu Karlu]], Central Australia.]] In [[geomorphology]] a '''nubbin''' is a small and gentle hill consisting a bedrock core dotted with rounded [[residual (geology)|residual]] [[block (geology)|block]]s.<ref name=Twidale1995/><ref>{{cite book |last=Gutiérrez |first=Francisco |last2=Gutiérrez |first2=Mateo |date=2016 |title=Landforms of the Earth: An Illustrated Guide |url= |location= |publisher=Springer International Publishing |page=104 |isbn=3319269453}}</ref> The blocks derive from disintegrated and [[weathering|weathered]] bedrock layers. In particular it is assumed that the boulders of the nubbins are the remnants of the outer one or two [[Exfoliation joint|exfoliation shell]]s that weathered underground, albeit some weathering can continue to occur once the boulders are exposed on surface.<ref name=Twidale1995/>
Nubbins form in a similar way to [[tor (landform)|castle koppies]] and [[bornhardt]]s and the three landforms can be seen as different expressions of the same phenomena.<ref name=Twidale1995>{{cite journal |last=Twidale |first=C.R.|author-link=Charles Rowland Twidale |date=1995 |title=Bornhardts, Boulders and Inselbergs |url= |journal=Cadernos do Laboratorio Xeolóxico de Laxe |publisher= |volume=20 |issue= |pages=347–380 |doi= |access-date= }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Withers |first=P.C. |last2= |first2= |date=2000 |title=Overview of granite outcrops in Western Australia |url=http://www.rswa.org.au/publications/Journal/83(3)/v83(3)withers.pdf |journal=Journal of the Royal Society of Western Australia |publisher= |volume=83 |issue= |pages=103-108 |doi= |access-date= }}</ref> Nubbins occur often in patterned groups.<ref name=Twidale1995/>
Nubbins can be found in humid [[tropical climate|tropical]] and [[monsoon climate]] areas. According to geomorphologist C.R. Twidale this is the environment where most nubbins form. Nubbins outside the humid or seasonally-humid tropics are [[relict (geology)|relict landforms]] formed in a humid and tropical past or form in areas of high subsurface humidity. Examples of localities with nubbins include [[Southwestern United States]], the [[MacDonnell Ranges]] in Central Australia and [[Namaqualand]] in Southern Africa.<ref name=Twidale1995/>
==See also== *[[Grus (geology)]] *[[Inselberg]] *[[Saprolite]]

{{Refimprove|date=March 2011}} '''Passenger Car Equivalent''' (PCE) or Passenger Car Unit (PCU) is a metric used in [[Transport engineering|Transportation Engineering]], to assess [[Traffic flow|traffic-flow rate]] on a highway.{{cite book |title= Development of passenger car equivalents for freeway merging sections |last= Ahuja |first= Amanpreet Singh |year= 2004 |publisher= ProQuest |isbn= 0-549-24044-6 |url= https://books.google.com/?id=6ay8gpgv5HUC}} A Passenger Car Equivalent is essentially the impact that a mode of transport has on traffic variables (such as headway, speed, density) compared to a single car. For example, typical values of PCE (or PCU) are:
*private car (including taxis or pick-up) 1 *motorcycle 0.5 *bicycle 0.2 *horse-drawn vehicle 4 *bus, tractor, truck 3.5 Highway capacity is measured in PCE/hour daily A common method used in the US is the density method. However, the PCU values derived from the density method are based on underlying homogeneous traffic concepts such as strict lane discipline, car following and a vehicle fleet that does not vary greatly in width. On the other hand, highways in [[India]], carry heterogeneous traffic, where road space is shared among many traffic modes with different physical dimensions. Loose lane discipline prevails; car following is not the norm. This complicates computing of PCE. Using multiple [[heuristic]] techniques, transportation engineers convert a mixed traffic stream into a hypothetical passenger-car stream. ==Methods== Many methods existTransport for London http://content.tfl.gov.uk/traffic-modelling-guidelines.pdf for determining passenger car units (PCUs)
examples:
* homogenization coefficient, * semi-empirical method, * Walker’s method, * headway method, * multiple [[linear regression]] method * simulation method. It may be appropriate to use different values for the same vehicle type according to circumstances. For example, in the UK in the 1960s and 1970s, bicycles were evaluated thus: *on rural roads 0.5 *on urban roads 0.33 *on roundabouts 0.5 *at traffic lights 0.2. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Passenger Car Equivalent}} [[Category:Transportation engineering]] [[Category:Equivalent units]] {{Road-stub}}

revision.text:
[[File:Pierre-Niton-Geneva-1.jpg|thumb|400px|The Pierres du Niton in Geneva harbor]] The '''Pierres du Niton''' (French for ''Neptune's Stones'') are two unusual rocks which are visible from [[Quai Gustave-Ador]] in the harbor of [[Lake Geneva]], [[Switzerland]]. They are remnants from the last [[ice age]], left by the [[Rhone glacier]]. The Repère Pierre du Niton is the name of the rock which is bigger and further from the shore.
The word ''Niton'' is derived from the ancient water god [[Neptune (mythology)|Neptune]], who was revered by the [[Gauls]] who settled at the lake, as old inscriptions in Geneva and [[Lausanne]] indicate.<ref>Répertoire des immeubles et objets classés. Service des monuments et sites. République et Canton de Genève. [[Éditions Georg]]. {{ISBN|2-8257-0126-2}}</ref>
Guillaume-Henri Dufour used the Repère as a height starting point by the development of the Dufourmaps from 1845 to 1864 in the graduation 1:100 000. At that time the height over sea level was estimated and decreed to be 376.86 m. Up to today, this stone forms the authoritative point of the [[Metres above the Sea (Switzerland)|Swiss height measurement system]]. However, the height was newly evaluated in 1902 to be 373.6 m over sea level. This is why the data in maps of Switzerland made before 1902 differ by 3.26 m from today's official values.
In the [[Bronze Age]], these stones likely had a spiritual significance and were used in religious ceremonies. This has been hypothesized due to square holes at the top of the larger stone, discovered in 1660, which seem to have been hewed by Middle Bronze Age (ca. 1500–1200 BC) axes.<ref name="geoerg2">Arts et monuments. Ville et Canton de Genève. Armand Brulhart et Erica Deuber-Pauli. Éditions Georg. {{ISBN|2-8257-0126-2}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{coord|46|12|20|N|6|09|16|E|region:CH-GE_type:landmark_source:kolossus-dewiki|display=title}}
[[Category:Geography of Geneva]] [[Category:Glacial erratics]]

revision.text:
The '''Southern Arctic Ecozone''', as defined by the [[Commission for Environmental Cooperation]] (CEC), is a [[Canada|Canadian]] terrestrial [[Ecozones of Canada|ecozone]] which spans the northern coast of mainland [[Northwest Territories]], most of northern mainland [[Nunavut]] excepting the northeast peninsula, and a portion of northwestern [[Quebec]]. Its two constituent territories are interrupted by [[Hudson Bay]].
It is sparsely populated, with less than 10,000 inhabitants in 17 major settlements, the largest of which is [[Rankin Inlet]]. About 80% of the population is [[Inuit]].<ref name="framework">{{Cite web |url=http://sis.agr.gc.ca/cansis/publications/ecostrat/index.html |title=A National Ecological Framework for Canada |year=1996 |publisher=Agriculture Canada, Environment Canada |accessdate=2014-05-10}}</ref>
It includes [[Ivvavik National Park]] and [[Tuktut Nogait National Park]].<ref name="ParksCanada">{{Cite web |url=http://www.pc.gc.ca/apprendre-learn/prof/itm2-crp-trc/htm/ecozone03_e.asp |title=Southern Arctic Ecozone |publisher=[[Parks Canada]] |accessdate=2008-02-07}}</ref>
==Geography== Its southern boundary demarcates the [[tree line]], and to the north it meets the [[Northern Arctic]] terrestrial ecozone and the [[Arctic Archipelago Marine]] ecozone. It was formed from glacial deposits left by retreating glaciers about 8,500 years ago, which amassed into [[moraine]]s cut by long [[esker]]s up to 100 km long.<ref name="landforms">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ec.gc.ca/soer-ree/English/vignettes/Terrestrial/sa/land.cfm |title=Landforms and Climate of the Southern Arctic Ecozone |work=Southern Arctic Ecozone |publisher=Environment Canada |accessdate=2008-02-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040703052802/http://www.ec.gc.ca/soer-ree/English/vignettes/Terrestrial/sa/land.cfm |archivedate=July 3, 2004 }}</ref> The scouring of the land by the 3 km thick glaciers left numerous depressions, some of which contained stray chunks of ice that, upon melting during warmer periods, created [[kettle lake]]s and ponds. The [[Precambrian]] [[granite]] bedrock of the [[Canadian Shield]] protrudes to the surface through other sedimentary deposits in some areas. Moreover, [[glacial erratic]] chunks of this rock may have been transported to other areas by the ice sheet, sometimes into surroundings with no common elements.<ref name="landforms" />
[[Permafrost]] occurs in a continuous, permanent sheet throughout the zone,<ref name="bernhardt">{{Cite web |url=http://canadianbiodiversity.mcgill.ca/english/ecozones/southernarctic/southernarctic.htm |title=Southern Arctic |work=Canada's Ecozones, Canadian Biodiversity project |last=Bernhardt |first=Torsten |publisher=[[McGill University]], Redpath Museum |accessdate=2008-02-07}}</ref> which consists primarily of rollings plains.<ref name="ParksCanada" /> Just a few centimetres from the surface in some parts, it prevents water from penetrating deep into the soil, hence pooling and creating waterlogged soil that freezes regularly.<ref name="landforms" /> Cyclic freezing and thawing of the soils results in irregular features throughout the terrain, including [[hummock]]s and [[polygon]]al shapes.
The land is characterised by "sprawling [[shrub]]lands, [[poor fen|wet sedge meadows]], and cold, clear [[lake]]s".<ref name="overview">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ec.gc.ca/soer-ree/English/vignettes/Terrestrial/sa/default.cfm |title=Treeless North |work=Southern Arctic Ecozone |publisher=Environment Canada |accessdate=2008-02-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060718094934/http://www.ec.gc.ca/soer-ree/English/vignettes/Terrestrial/sa/default.cfm |archivedate=July 18, 2006 }}</ref>
==Climate== This ecozone experiences short summers which are cool and moist, with mean July temperatures of about 10 °C.<ref name="ParksCanada" /> Winters are long, dark and bitterly cold, with average January mean temperatures of -30 °C.<ref name="ParksCanada" /> The area in Quebec is relatively warmer, with mean January temperatures of -18 °C.<ref name="bernhardt" />
Annual [[Precipitation (meteorology)|precipitation]] increases eastward through the zone, with 250 mm in the west and no more than 500 mm in the east.<ref name="landforms" /> It also varies [[latitude|latitudinally]], with about twice as much precipitation at its southern edge than at the northern fringes.<ref name="ParksCanada" />
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Ecozones and ecoregions of Nunavut]] [[Category:Ecozones and ecoregions of the Northwest Territories]] [[Category:Geography of Quebec]] [[Category:Geography of the Arctic]]

A '''spatiotemporal database''' is a database that manages both space and time information. Common examples include: * Tracking of moving objects, which typically can occupy only a single position at a given time. * A database of wireless communication networks, which may exist only for a short timespan within a geographic region. * An index of species in a given geographic region, where over time additional species may be introduced or existing species migrate or die out. * Historical tracking of plate tectonic activity.
Spatiotemporal databases are an extension of [[spatial database]]s. A spatiotemporal database embodies spatial, [[temporal database|temporal]], and spatiotemporal database concepts, and captures spatial and temporal aspects of data and deals with: * geometry changing over time and/or * location of objects moving over invariant geometry (known variously as ''moving objects databases''<ref name="GütingSchneider2005">{{cite book|author1=Ralf Hartmut Güting|author2=Markus Schneider|title=Moving Objects Databases|year=2005|publisher=Academic Press|isbn=978-0-12-088799-6}}</ref> or [[real-time locating system]]s).
==Implementations== Although there exist numerous [[relational database]]s with spatial extensions, spatiotemporal databases are not based on the relational model for practical reasons, chiefly among them that the data is multi-dimensional, capturing complex structures and behaviours.
As of 2008, there are no [[RDBMS]] products with spatiotemporal extensions. There are some products such as the open-source [[TerraLib]] which use a [[middleware]] approach storing their data in a relational database. Unlike in the pure spatial domain, there are however no official or ''de facto'' standards for spatio-temporal data models and their querying. In general, the theory of this area is also less well-developed.<ref name="HallLeahy2008">{{cite book|author1=Brent Hall|author2=Michael G. Leahy|title=Open Source Approaches in Spatial Data Handling|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JZNuu8XODQMC&pg=PA127|year=2008|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-3-540-74830-4|pages=126–128}}</ref> Another approach is the constraint database system such as MLPQ (Management of Linear Programming Queries).<ref name="Revesz2010">{{cite book|author=Peter Revesz|title=Introduction to Databases: From Biological to Spatio-Temporal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gnVdtvb9wH0C&pg=PA262|year=2010|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-1-84996-094-6|page=262}}</ref><ref>http://www.cse.unl.edu/~revesz/MLPQ/mlpq.htm</ref>
[[GeoMesa]] is an [[open-source]] distributed spatiotemporal index built on top of [[Bigtable]]-style databases using an implementation of the [[Z-order_curve]] to create a multi-dimensional index combining space and time.
==See also== * {{section link|Geographic information system|Adding the dimension of time}} * [[Historical geographic information system]] * [[Locating engine]] * [[Multimedia database]] * [[Structure mining]] * [[Time geography]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== ===Organizations=== * http://vldb.org (Very Large Databases) * http://www.dexa.org (Database and Expert Systems Applications)
===Implementations=== * http://dna.fernuni-hagen.de/secondo/ (Secondo)
{{Data}}

{{Multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=February 2017}} {{unreferenced|date=February 2017}} }} {{Infobox street | name = Turhan Cemal Beriker Boulevard | marker_image = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | alternate_name = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_map = | caption = | map_type = | latitude = | longitude = | map_size = | map_caption = | map_alt = | other_name = | former_names = | part_of = {{TUR-P|1}}/{{BAB-E|5}} (original roadway, up to the 1980s, when the state roadways' numbering system changed to present numbering system)
{{TUR-D|400}}/{{BAB-E|90}} (present state roadway and [[international E-road network]] numbering scheme). | namesake = | type = | owner = | maint = | length = | length_m = | length_ft = | length_km = 13.7 | length_mi = 8.5 | length_ref = | length_notes = | width = | area = | addresses = | location = [[Adana]] | arrondissement = | quarter = | postal_code = | metro = | coordinates = | direction_a = | terminus_a = | direction_b = | terminus_b = Just after the Kennedy Bridge ({{lang-tr|Kennedy Köprüsü}}), where it becomes Girne Boulevard. | junction = | north = | east = | south = | west = | main_contractor = | cost = | references = | commissioning_date = | construction_start_date = | completion_date = | inauguration_date = 1950s | demolition_date = | designer = | known_for = Trucks going from [[Europe]] (Sweden, Germany, Denmark, France, Greece, Norway, Netherlands, Poland, Bulgaria, Yugoslavia, Romania, rarely Spain and Portugal) to the [[Arab states of the Persian Gulf|Persian Gulf countries]] in the [[Middle East|Mid-East]], especially Iraq, and Kuwait, were passed through this boulevard. (at that time, a road with a lane in each direction). | status = | website = }} The '''Turhan Cemal Beriker Boulevard''' is a major thoroughfare through the [[Seyhan]] district of [[Adana]], [[Turkey]]. With the Girne ([[Kyrenia]]) and [[Cemal Gürsel]] Boulevards, the Turhan Cemal Beriker Boulevard forms the D400 state roadway through the city of [[Adana]]. Historically, the boulevard is located on the P1 state roadway and E5. In the past, a large volume of freight traffic from Europe passed along this road en route to the [[Middle East]], especially after the opening of the [[Bosphorus Bridge]] on 30 October 1973, the [[Republic Day (Turkey)|50th anniversary of the founding of the]] [[Turkey|Republic of Turkey]]. As the [[economy of Turkey]] became capable of producing goods for the [[Middle East]], trucks from Europe stopped using this route. The road is named after Turhan Cemal Beriker, former mayor of Adana. The Turhan Cemal Beriker Boulevard is maintained by both the [[General Directorate of Highways (Turkey)|General Directorate of Highways of the Republic of Turkey]], and the Metropolitan Municipality of [[Adana]]. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Roads in Turkey]] {{turkey-stub}} {{road-stub}}
